channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: How to build Moon roads using focused beams of sunlight
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03207-y

Experiments with lasers reveal a way to melt lunar dust into solid paving slabs.
item.dc:title: How to build Moon roads using focused beams of sunlight
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson

item.title: Bamboo gains super strength thanks to an ingredient from within
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03108-0

A component of bamboo itself can be used to bind the plant’s cells to form a strong material — no petrochemical glue needed.
item.dc:title: Bamboo gains super strength thanks to an ingredient from within

item.title: Mental health: The invisible effects of neglected tropical diseases
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02973-z

The psychological burden of disability and stigma has been overlooked, to the detriment of those affected and their carers.
item.dc:title: Mental health: The invisible effects of neglected tropical diseases
item.dc:creator: Simon Makin

item.title: Reproducibility trial: 246 biologists get different results from same data sets
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03177-1

Wide distribution of findings shows how analytical choices drive conclusions.
item.dc:title: Reproducibility trial: 246 biologists get different results from same data sets
item.dc:creator: Anil Oza

item.title: AI reads text from ancient Herculaneum scroll for the first time
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03212-1

Machine-learning technique reveals Greek words in CT scans of rolled-up papyrus.
item.dc:title: AI reads text from ancient Herculaneum scroll for the first time
item.dc:creator: Jo Marchant

item.title: This is the largest map of the human brain ever made
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03192-2

Researchers catalogue more than 3,000 different types of cell in our most complex organ.
item.dc:title: This is the largest map of the human brain ever made
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: Clostridioides difficile infection drives neuronal inflammation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02640-3

Infection by the bacterium Clostridioides difficile can be fatal in a clinical setting. Insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying such infection might offer targets for the search to develop new treatments.
item.dc:title: Clostridioides difficile infection drives neuronal inflammation
item.dc:creator: Klaus Aktories

item.title: Climate and conservation science persevere in the face of major challenges
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03087-2

But research will need to renew and redouble efforts to provide solutions as the climate emergency deepens.
item.dc:title: Climate and conservation science persevere in the face of major challenges
item.dc:creator: Simon Baker

item.title: Gene edits move pig organs closer to human transplantation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03206-z

Monkeys with CRISPR-edited pig kidneys survive for more than a year, and why our brains struggle to count more than four objects.
item.dc:title: Gene edits move pig organs closer to human transplantation
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Shamini Bundell

item.title: Where is the strongest research focus on the environment?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02869-y

The alignment of high-quality research to Sustainable Development Goals on climate and conservation varies widely between the world’s regions.
item.dc:title: Where is the strongest research focus on the environment?
item.dc:creator: Simon Baker
Bec Crew

item.title: Arenium-ion-catalysed halodealkylation of fully alkylated silanes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06646-9

A new method is described that uses arenium-ion-catalysed halodealkylation of silanes with four alkyl groups, typically considered synthetic dead ends, to convert Me4Si and related quaternary silanes into orthogonally substituted (functionalized) silanes.
item.dc:title: Arenium-ion-catalysed halodealkylation of fully alkylated silanes
item.dc:creator: Tao He
Hendrik F. T. Klare
Martin Oestreich

item.title: Genotyping, sequencing and analysis of 140,000 adults from Mexico City
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06595-3

Genotype and exome sequencing of 150,000 participants and whole-genome sequencing of 9,950 selected individuals recruited into the Mexico City Prospective Study constitute a valuable, publicly available resource of non-European sequencing data.
item.dc:title: Genotyping, sequencing and analysis of 140,000 adults from Mexico City

item.title: Unraveling the functional dark matter through global metagenomics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06583-7

A computational approach to generate reference-free protein families from the sequence space in metagenomes reveals an enormously diverse functional space.
item.dc:title: Unraveling the functional dark matter through global metagenomics

item.title: Precipitation regime changes in High Mountain Asia driven by cleaner air
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06619-y

Dipolar precipitation change in High Mountain Asia during summer is primarily driven by weakened westerly jet and decadal variations in the South Asian monsoon, and the dipolar pattern is projected to shift to a monopolar wetting trend in the 2040s.
item.dc:title: Precipitation regime changes in High Mountain Asia driven by cleaner air
item.dc:creator: Jie Jiang
Tianjun Zhou
Yun Qian
Chao Li
Fengfei Song
Hongmei Li
Xiaolong Chen
Wenxia Zhang
Ziming Chen

item.title: Apoptotic stress causes mtDNA release during senescence and drives the SASP
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06621-4

During senescence, minority mitochondrial outer membrane permeabilization leads to the release of mtDNA into the cytosol through BAX and BAK macropores, in turn activating the cGAS–STING pathway, a major regulator of the senescence-associated secretory phenotype.
item.dc:title: Apoptotic stress causes mtDNA release during senescence and drives the SASP

item.title: Mexican Biobank advances population and medical genomics of diverse ancestries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06560-0

Nationwide genomic biobank in Mexico unravels demographic history and complex trait architecture from 6,057 individuals.

item.title: State estimation of a physical system with unknown governing equations
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06574-8

A parametrization strategy for stochastic variational inference with Markov Gaussian processes is presented for state estimation of a physical system whose underlying dynamical equations are partially or completely unknown.
item.dc:title: State estimation of a physical system with unknown governing equations
item.dc:creator: Kevin Course
Prasanth B. Nair

item.title: Learning from prepandemic data to forecast viral escape
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06617-0

EVEscape, a flexible framework using deep learning and biophysical structural information, enables early identification of concerning mutations in viruses with pandemic potential, facilitating the development of vaccines and therapeutics.
item.dc:title: Learning from prepandemic data to forecast viral escape
item.dc:creator: Nicole N. Thadani
Sarah Gurev
Pascal Notin
Noor Youssef
Nathan J. Rollins
Daniel Ritter
Chris Sander
Yarin Gal
Debora S. Marks

item.title: High-fidelity gates and mid-circuit erasure conversion in an atomic qubit
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06438-1

This study reports gates between qubits encoded in the nuclear spin state of Yb atoms trapped in optical tweezers, reaching very high fidelity and demonstrating mid-circuit conversion of errors into erasure errors.
item.dc:title: High-fidelity gates and mid-circuit erasure conversion in an atomic qubit
item.dc:creator: Shuo Ma
Genyue Liu

Guido Pupillo
Shruti Puri
Jeff D. Thompson

item.title: Ultra-fast deep-learned CNS tumour classification during surgery
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06615-2

Sturgeon is a pretrained neural network that uses incremental results from nanopore sequencing to rapidly classify central nervous system tumours and can be used to aid critical decision-making during surgery.
item.dc:title: Ultra-fast deep-learned CNS tumour classification during surgery

item.title: Erasure conversion in a high-fidelity Rydberg quantum simulator
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06516-4

Erasure conversion and detection are used in a Rydberg quantum simulator to create Bell states with high fidelity, competitive with other state-of-the-art platforms.
item.dc:title: Erasure conversion in a high-fidelity Rydberg quantum simulator
item.dc:creator: Pascal Scholl
Adam L. Shaw
Richard Bing-Shiun Tsai
Ran Finkelstein
Joonhee Choi
Manuel Endres

item.title: Structures illustrate step-by-step mitochondrial transcription initiation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06643-y

A cryogenic electron microscopy study presents structures characterizing the initiation of RNA synthesis by yeast mitochondrial RNA polymerase at single-nucleotide addition steps.
item.dc:title: Structures illustrate step-by-step mitochondrial transcription initiation
item.dc:creator: Quinten Goovaerts
Jiayu Shen
Brent De Wijngaert
Urmimala Basu
Smita S. Patel
Kalyan Das

item.title: Doping of molecular semiconductors through proton-coupled electron transfer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06504-8

Proton-coupled electron-transfer reactions are used to achieve efficient chemical doping of organic semiconductor thin films under ambient conditions, and a reference-electrode-free, resistive pH sensor based on the method is proposed.
item.dc:title: Doping of molecular semiconductors through proton-coupled electron transfer
item.dc:creator: Masaki Ishii
Yu Yamashita
Shun Watanabe
Katsuhiko Ariga
Jun Takeya

item.title: Design and testing of a humanized porcine donor for xenotransplantation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06594-4

Using kidneys from a genetically engineered porcine donor transplanted into a cynomolgus monkey model, the design, creation and long-term function of kidney grafts supporting life are explored.
item.dc:title: Design and testing of a humanized porcine donor for xenotransplantation

item.title: Flexible circuit mechanisms for context-dependent song sequencing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06632-1

Insights into the underlying neuronal circuitry of the Drosophila song production system are provided using song patterning of males near versus far from the female.
item.dc:title: Flexible circuit mechanisms for context-dependent song sequencing
item.dc:creator: Frederic A. Roemschied

item.title: High-fidelity parallel entangling gates on a neutral-atom quantum computer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06481-y

The realization of two-qubit entangling gates with 99.5% fidelity on up to 60 rubidium atoms in parallel is reported, surpassing the surface-code threshold for error correction and laying the groundwork for neutral-atom quantum computers.
item.dc:title: High-fidelity parallel entangling gates on a neutral-atom quantum computer

item.title: A planetary collision afterglow and transit of the resultant debris cloud
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06573-9

Infrared brightening and luminosity observations from a young, solar-like star suggest a collision between two exoplanets producing a hot, highly extended post-impact remnant and transit of the debris causing the visible light eclipse of the host star.
item.dc:title: A planetary collision afterglow and transit of the resultant debris cloud

item.title: A guide to the Nature Index
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03091-6

A description of the terminology and methodology used in this supplement, and a guide to the functionality that is available free online at natureindex.com.
item.dc:title: A guide to the Nature Index

item.title: Why BMI is flawed — and how to redefine obesity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03143-x

The main diagnostic test for obesity — the body mass index — accounts for only height and weight, leaving out a slew of factors that influence body fat and health.
item.dc:title: Why BMI is flawed — and how to redefine obesity
item.dc:creator: McKenzie Prillaman

item.title: ‘Abortion tests’ developed in Poland spark concern
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03129-9

Scientists are questioning the reliability and ethics of tests to detect abortion drugs in biological samples.
item.dc:title: ‘Abortion tests’ developed in Poland spark concern
item.dc:creator: Layal Liverpool

item.title: Taking time
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03167-3

The write stuff.
item.dc:title: Taking time
item.dc:creator: John Gilbey

item.title: The technique that can find a system’s state through data alone
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03070-x

Pinpointing the state of a complex system is tricky, especially when the underlying mathematical equations aren’t known. But a data-driven technique makes light work of it — and could even change the way that models are formulated.
item.dc:title: The technique that can find a system’s state through data alone
item.dc:creator: Brendan Keith

item.title: Facing racism in science, ‘I decided to prove them wrong’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03205-0

Immunologist Dequina Nicholas shares why mentorship is crucial for first-generation scientists.
item.dc:title: Facing racism in science, ‘I decided to prove them wrong’
item.dc:creator: Lesley Evans Ogden

item.title: Violent collision rocks a young planetary system
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03069-4

When two worlds collide, they leave more than the shambles of dusty ejecta. Astronomers have detected light from a post-collision remnant, providing the best evidence so far for planetary-scale collisions in exoplanetary systems.
item.dc:title: Violent collision rocks a young planetary system
item.dc:creator: Carl Melis

item.title: Polar researchers strive for progress despite adverse world events
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03088-1

The pandemic and the invasion of Ukraine have had a significant impact on international collaboration and field access.
item.dc:title: Polar researchers strive for progress despite adverse world events
item.dc:creator: Rachel Nuwer

item.title: Learn from the past to predict viral pandemics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02931-9

The COVID-19 pandemic highlighted the need to understand the emergence of viral variants, given that these can have implications for vaccination success. A bioinformatics tool offers a way to predict viral evolution.
item.dc:title: Learn from the past to predict viral pandemics
item.dc:creator: Nash D. Rochman
Eugene V. Koonin

item.title: ‘Incredible’ asteroid sample ferried to Earth is rich in the building blocks of life
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03178-0

Samples of asteroid Bennu delivered by the OSIRIS-REx mission contain carbon, water and other ingredients from the primordial Solar System.
item.dc:title: ‘Incredible’ asteroid sample ferried to Earth is rich in the building blocks of life
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: Daily briefing: Fossilized footprints show people’s first steps into the Americas
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03213-0

Human footprints might be the oldest direct evidence that people lived in the Americas thousands of years earlier than thought. Plus, gene editing makes chickens flu-resistant and how to lower the risk of a Nipah virus pandemic.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Fossilized footprints show people’s first steps into the Americas
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Achieving UN climate goals needs purposeful, persistent action from science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03090-7

To contribute fully to the Sustainable Development Goals, global research must change gear.
item.dc:title: Achieving UN climate goals needs purposeful, persistent action from science
item.dc:creator: James Mitchell Crow

item.title: How AlphaFold and other AI tools could help us prepare for the next pandemic
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03201-4

Researchers are using machine-learning programs to predict the evolution of viruses and design vaccines.
item.dc:title: How AlphaFold and other AI tools could help us prepare for the next pandemic
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Half a million children die of malaria every year. Finally we can change that
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03173-5

With two vaccines available, this killer disease could now be eliminated — but will the world pull together to make it happen?
item.dc:title: Half a million children die of malaria every year. Finally we can change that

item.title: Pig-to-primate organ transplants require genetic modifications of donor
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02817-w

A raft of alterations to the pig genome — removing three antigen-encoding genes, adding seven human genes and eliminating a retrovirus — allows kidneys to be transplanted into monkeys, with implications for clinical trials.
item.dc:title: Pig-to-primate organ transplants require genetic modifications of donor
item.dc:creator: Muhammad M. Mohiuddin

item.title: Three scientists on the front line of climate and conservation research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03089-0

By bearing firsthand witness to how the climate crisis is affecting life and livelihoods, their fieldwork directly informs policy to protect vulnerable sites.
item.dc:title: Three scientists on the front line of climate and conservation research
item.dc:creator: Sandy Ong
Andy Tay

item.title: Monkey survives for two years after gene-edited pig-kidney transplant
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03176-2

Survival time is one of the longest for any interspecies transplant — and moves pig organs closer to human use.
item.dc:title: Monkey survives for two years after gene-edited pig-kidney transplant
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Sustainability: draw on decades of social-science research
item.content:encoded:

Sustainability: draw on decades of social-science research

Snippets from Nature’s past.

item.title: 'This doesn't just fall on women': computer scientists reflect on gender biases in STEM
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03199-9

Two researchers share their experiences and discuss the inequalities that impact women in the computer sciences.
item.dc:title: 'This doesn't just fall on women': computer scientists reflect on gender biases in STEM
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe

item.title: Daily briefing: Human voices are the scariest sound in the savanna
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03202-3

Recordings of human voices evoke more fear among animals living in the South African savanna than do snarls from lions. Plus, an economic historian who mined 200 years of gender pay gap data wins a Nobel Prize and researchers are seeking to understand the human body’s heat limit.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Human voices are the scariest sound in the savanna
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Nipah virus is deadly — but smart policy changes can help quell pandemic risk
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03162-8

Repeated outbreaks increase the risk of a Nipah strain emerging that is better at spreading.
item.dc:title: Nipah virus is deadly — but smart policy changes can help quell pandemic risk
item.dc:creator: Thekkumkara Surendran Anish

item.title: ‘I wrote my first piece of code at seven’: women share highs and lows in computer science for Ada Lovelace Day
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03146-8

Ada Lovelace was a visionary who first recognized the potential of computer programming. Almost two centuries on, six women in computer science and technology reflect on their experiences in the field.
item.dc:title: ‘I wrote my first piece of code at seven’: women share highs and lows in computer science for Ada Lovelace Day
item.dc:creator: Janet Abbate
Shobhana Narasimhan
Sana Odeh

Soraia Raupp Musse
Verena Rieser

item.title: C. R. Rao, statistician who transformed data analytics (1920–2023)
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03200-5

Pioneer of powerful tools for sifting data and optimizing device designs.
item.dc:title: C. R. Rao, statistician who transformed data analytics (1920–2023)
item.dc:creator: Shyamal D. Peddada
Ravindra Khattree

item.title: AI’s potential to accelerate drug discovery needs a reality check
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03172-6

Companies say the technology will contribute to faster drug development. Independent verification and clinical trials will determine whether this claim holds up.
item.dc:title: AI’s potential to accelerate drug discovery needs a reality check

item.title: How ChatGPT and other AI tools could disrupt scientific publishing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03144-w

A world of AI-assisted writing and reviewing might transform the nature of the scientific paper.
item.dc:title: How ChatGPT and other AI tools could disrupt scientific publishing
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: Dear journals: stop hoarding our papers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03196-y

Why single-submission policies need to die (and what to do in the meantime).
item.dc:title: Dear journals: stop hoarding our papers
item.dc:creator: Dritjon Gruda

item.dc:creator: Anthony D. Campbell

item.title: My quest for hidden treasures in Sri Lanka’s flora
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03164-6

Sri Lankan taxonomist Bhathiya Gopallawa tapped into a network of early-career researchers to unearth a botanic gem in the tropical forest undergrowth.
item.dc:title: My quest for hidden treasures in Sri Lanka’s flora
item.dc:creator: Manasee Weerathunga

item.title: Why women earn less than men: Nobel for economic historian who probed pay gap
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03190-4

Claudia Goldin mined 200 years of data to show that greater economic growth did not lead to wage parity, nor to more women in the workplace.
item.dc:title: Why women earn less than men: Nobel for economic historian who probed pay gap
item.dc:creator: Philip Ball

item.title: Daily briefing: Atoms do their first basic calculation in a new type of quantum computer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03194-0

A new kind of quantum computer uses a high-resolution microscope to control the electron spins of titanium atoms. Plus, the Universe-mapping Euclid telescope fixes the wobble that threatened its mission and why our brains find it easy to eyeball four things but not five.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Atoms do their first basic calculation in a new type of quantum computer
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Postdoc career optimism rebounds after COVID in global Nature survey
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03163-7

Postdoctoral researchers still feel as though they are academia’s drudge labourers, but have more confidence about job prospects in a post-pandemic world.
item.dc:title: Postdoc career optimism rebounds after COVID in global Nature survey
item.dc:creator: Linda Nordling

item.title: Extreme heat harms health — what is the human body’s limit?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02482-z

As deadly heatwaves become more common, researchers are studying what people can tolerate.
item.dc:title: Extreme heat harms health — what is the human body’s limit?
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

item.title: 3D printing tackles tricky materials with help from tiny crystals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03037-y

Technique that uses a molecular ‘glue’ allows 3D printing to make objects from challenging materials such as semiconductors.
item.dc:title: 3D printing tackles tricky materials with help from tiny crystals

item.title: ‘Immense relief’: Universe-mapping Euclid telescope fixes problem that threatened mission
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03174-4

The European Space Agency says a software patch restored stability to its new cosmic mapper — but slower operations could extend the mission.
item.dc:title: ‘Immense relief’: Universe-mapping Euclid telescope fixes problem that threatened mission
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Gene therapies for rare diseases are under threat. Scientists hope to save them
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03109-z

As industry steps aside, scientists seek innovative ways to make sure expensive treatments can reach people who need them.
item.dc:title: Gene therapies for rare diseases are under threat. Scientists hope to save them
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: M. S. Swaminathan (1925–2023), leader of India’s ‘green revolution’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03175-3

Agricultural scientist who introduced crops to end famine in India in the 1960s.
item.dc:title: M. S. Swaminathan (1925–2023), leader of India’s ‘green revolution’
item.dc:creator: Gayathri Vaidyanathan

item.title: US science agencies on track to hit 25-year funding low
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03135-x

Despite last year’s CHIPS and Science Act, which was meant to boost innovation, report predicts that Congress will cut spending on science.
item.dc:title: US science agencies on track to hit 25-year funding low
item.dc:creator: Jeff Tollefson

item.title: Daily briefing: Mammals probably evolved same-sex sexual behaviour several times
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03185-1

Same-sex sexual behaviour seems to have evolved as a way to smooth out social relationships when mammals started living in groups. Plus, a dispatch from a Ukrainian scientist in the trenches and how embracing the command line opens up the world of computational biology.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Mammals probably evolved same-sex sexual behaviour several times
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: How to craft a research project with non-academic collaborators
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03140-0

If you’re working with indigeneous researchers, citizen scientists or local communities, find out about their expectations, including ones around payment and authorship.
item.dc:title: How to craft a research project with non-academic collaborators
item.dc:creator: Dom Byrne

item.title: W. Jason Morgan, discoverer of plate tectonics (1935–2023)
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03145-9

Geophysicist who showed how segments of Earth’s crust move.
item.dc:title: W. Jason Morgan, discoverer of plate tectonics (1935–2023)
item.dc:creator: Lawrence M. Cathles

item.title: Your brain finds it easy to size up four objects but not five — here’s why
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03136-w

Neuron activity shows that the brain uses different systems for counting up to four, and for five or more.
item.dc:title: Your brain finds it easy to size up four objects but not five — here’s why
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: How carrots became orange: genomics get at the root of the matter
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03035-0

The vegetable was domesticated roughly 1,200 years ago but was yellow or purple for centuries.
item.dc:title: How carrots became orange: genomics get at the root of the matter

item.title: New kind of quantum computer made using high-resolution microscope
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03141-z

Individual atoms on a surface do their first basic calculation.
item.dc:title: New kind of quantum computer made using high-resolution microscope
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi
